metadata.title: A materials driven approach for understanding single entity nano impact electrochemistry

sections.text:
Available online at www.sciencedirect.com
Review Article A materials driven approach for understanding single entity nano impact electrochemistry Keith J. Stevenson 1 and Kristina Tschulik 2 , ∗
We discuss here the design of functional nanoparticles and their study at the single entity level using nanoparticle impact electroanalysis (NIA). In particular, developments in electrochemical amplification (ECA) and transformative nanoparticle impact analysis (T-NIA) will be described that enable a better characterization of functional nanomaterials and their reactivity in their native (liquid) environment. This review highlights some outstanding works from the past two years that demonstrate the rapid progression in single entity nano-impact electrochemistry and discusses the remaining challenges to be overcome.

Besides conventional high-resolution imaging in acuum techniques such as electron microscopy (SEM, EM) or chemically blind solution phase analysis, such s dynamic light scattering (DLS) or nanoparticle trackng analysis (NTA), electrochemical characterization of anoparticles in their “native”, that is usually liquid, enironment has gained popularity. This surge in interest s not least due to the fact that electrochemically large

At the same time, ingle entity electrochemical studies can conveniently e performed [2] , for instance by immersion of an elecrode in a suspension of the nanoparticles to be studied.
anoparticle impact electroanalysis (NIA) is an emerging ethodology for electrochemical characterization of sinle NPs and in the development of ultra-low detection chemes in electroanalysis. Here we broadly define NIA s any method based on the electrochemical detection of iscrete NPs in solution as they collide with the surface f an electrode [3–5] .
y employing potentiostatic [4, 5] , galvanostatic [6] or poentiodynamic [7 ●●, 8 ●●] regimes at the electrode, these anoparticle collision events may be “turn on” or “turn ff” events, causing an increase or a decrease, respectively, f the electrochemical signal (current or potential). Durng “turn off” the electrode catalyzes a reaction, which s decreased (turned off) in the presence of a blocking pecies, such as a non-conductive or catalytically inactive article or micelle [9] . Since this usually does not allow n in depth analysis of the impacting material, these type f “blocking” nanoimpacts will not be considered in this hort review, but we refer to recent excellent reviews by ong et al. [10] , Compton et al. [11] and White et al. [12] for quantitative survey of the recent developments.

n the electrochemical amplification (ECA) method the ndicator reaction is the electrochemical conversion (oxiation or reduction) of a solution phase redox species at he surface of the impacting nanomaterial [13, 14] . Typial indicator reactions in ECA are the electrooxidation of ydrazine (N 2 H 4 ) [ 4, 15 –17 ●●], hydrogen [8, 18] , sodium orohydride (NaBH 4 ) [19] or water [20] and electroreducion of protons [21, 22 ●] or oxygen [23, 24] .
n transformative nano impact analysis (T-NIA) the indiator reaction is a conversion of the particle under study, or instance the oxidation of metals (Ag, [5,25,26 ●●,27] Au 28, 29] ,...) or the reduction of metal oxides (Fe 3 O 4 [30 ●] ,

The larger number of T-NIA indicator reactions originate from the fact that ECA is limited to typically inner-sphere reactions with much slower reaction kinetics at the indicator electrode as that at the single entity under study. Consequently, the selection of indicator electrodes is a crucial factor in ECA. Otherwise the background reaction at the microelectrode would obscure the “turn on” signal during ECA and the concentration of the indicator redox species in front of the electrode would constantly be depleted to a significant extent. In T-NIA the choice of electrode material is more flexible as possible side reactions with the electrolyte are less problematic. Most frequently, conductive but inert C, Au and Pt microelectrodes are employed as indicator electrodes in ECA and T-NIA, in addition to that Hg [38 ●] , boron doped diamond (BDD) [39] , or Bi [40] microelectrodes are preferred in selected cases. We note that little attention has yet been given to choosing a “reactive” indicator electrode as part of the signal readout and detection scheme to improve detection limits and analytical sensitivity [38,40,55] .

In this short review we will highlight recent developments in ECA and T-NIA that enable a better characterization of functional nanomaterials and their reactivity in their native (liquid) environment. These additional insights provide impetus to efficiently design better functional materials for sensing, catalysis and energy conversion, as well as to provide experimental aid to theoretical underpinnings of NIA [41–44] . Yet NIA methods are still far from being a standard analysis tool in electrochemistry [45,46] .
Bimetallic nanoparticles—alloy and core-shell structures Multicomponent nanoparticles enable the combination of different functionalities within a single entity and hence the adjustment of biocompatibility as well as optical and catalytic properties. The synthesis of these particles is challenging and NIA is a promising alternative technique for standard particle characterization in synthesis and application labs as DLS and UV–vis provide no to little compositional insights and TEM-EDX analysis is very demanding in terms of investment, operation and throughput. While NIA has very recently been demonstrated for bimetallic AuAg and AgHg nanoparticles, its application to analysis of bimetallic systems is still in its infancy.

Thus, the authors demonstrated that NIA can provide in depth characterization of bimetallic particles yielding structural information, particle, core and shell sizes as well as information on their elemental composition.
Magnetic nanoparticles Magnetic nanoparticles are a second class of functional nanoparticles that have been studied successfully by NIA. Tschulik et al. [30] demonstrated that the mixed metal oxide Fe 3 O 4 can be sized by T-NIA using two different indicator reactions, oxidation to Fe 3 + and reduction to Fe 2 + in phosphate buffer electrolyte at a carbon indicator electrode, allowing to validate quantitative conversion by electrochemical means.
The manipulation of such magnetic nanoparticles by a magnetic field has been used to increase the number of impacts during NIA, which allows stochastically relevant particle analysis even at low particle concentrations. This approach has been employed both, for T-NIA by the group of Crespilho [50] employing Prussian blue modified Fe 3 O 4 impacting an Au microelectrode and for ECA by Robinson et al. [51 ●] using hydrazine oxidation at Pt iron oxide hybrid nanoparticles ( Figure 3 ). In the latter case a 6-fold increase of particle impacts at gold microband electrodes was seen, demonstrating the potential of this magnetic control for sensitive nanoparticle detection in microfluidic systems employing particle concentrations as little as ca. 100 fM. This method was further developed by Yoo et al. [52] , allowing to use attomolar concentrations of magnetic particles impacting magnetized microelectrodes. At the same time NIA was able to reveal magnetic field enhanced agglomeration of magnetic particles,

Bio-sensing at single nanoparticles The growing demand for reliable and high-throughput methods in bio-sensing resulted in great progress in implementing electrochemical sensing at microelectrodes in microfluidic and even nanofluidic systems [54] . Thanks to the small electrodes and liquid volumes needed and the ultra-low limits of detection, NIA is perfectly suitable as an analytical tool in these miniaturized systems [55,56] . Specific sensing of biomolecules by ECA is usually difficult, as the adsorption of these species (DNA, RNA,…) at Pt NPs blocks their catalytic surface sides and hence unspecific turn-off of impacts result in NIA. Stevenson, Crooks and coworkers [57 ●●] used Exonuclease I for enzymatic digestion of the single stranded DNA (ssDNA) they had previously attached to a Pt NP surface to partially re-activate the Pt NPs surface, and hence to increase the number of catalytic impacts ( Figure 4 ). This general methodology opens up a path to turn originally unspecific turn-off ECA into a specific turn-on ECA. Very recently this approach was implemented in a microfluidic system to detect nano- and sub-nanomolar concentrations of microRNA by ECA at Pt NPs that were modified with a complimentary ssDNA. Thus, a microRNA–ssDNA conjugate modified Pt NP is formed that is inactive for hydrazine oxidation. Upon edition of the enzyme duplex specific nuclease (DSN), this conjugate “shell” is partially removed from the Pt NP surface. Hence the detection of the microRNA is achieved by turn on ECA [58] .

onclusions he applications of electrochemical single entity analysis re emerging quickly, thanks to the fact that both ECA nd T-NIA are versatile tools that can provide valuable nformation on a variety of different nanoparticles, redox pecies and biomolecules. The recent developments disussed herein highlight the great potential this methodolgy has with respect to development of functional nanoaterials in fields intercepting chemistry, physics, biology nd medicine.
owever, a number of challenges remain to be addressed n the future. One of the most crucial ones is the effect of article aggregation and agglomeration that either needs o be prevented or at least has to be monitored during IA. Aggregation is particularly important for ECA where ften impact frequencies are analyzed with respect to adition of a certain target substances or physical triggers nd hence unaccounted for aggregation may cause mis-
urrent Opinion in Electrochemistry 2017, 6 :38–45
nterpretation of the experimental data [16] . In T-NIA he charge transferred per impact may directly serve as n indicator for aggregation and should thus be moniored throughout NIA experiments. Similarly, current (or otential) step heights may serve as an in-situ size indiator in ECA. Alongside with this monitoring of aggreation, the search for indicator reactions with more faorable characteristics (e.g. stable to pH, highly soluble, ast kinetics, formation of non-gaseous products) than hyrazine is desirable, which has to be associated with findng a suitable inactive indicator electrode or methods of ownsizing or deactivating the electrodes used, so as to reuce background currents to the minimal possible backround signal. Alternatively, the identification of particletabilizing ligands that do not block charge transfer to the anoparticle, but minimize aggregation and agglomeraion in the system under study is desirable. Such recent ystems of DNA coated Pt nanoparticles serve as examles [55,57,58,59] .
lso the stochastic aspect of all NIA experiments, both in erms of the particle impacting out of a mixture of differnt ones–with more or less widely distributed properties, nd the electrochemical signal detected during this event, as to be considered. In consequence, the detection and nalysis of a large number of individual stochastic events > 25) is mandatory to draw reliable conclusions based on he obtained data.
rovided these issues can be addressed appropriately, the pplication of NIA is expected to emerge quickly so as to nswer many more of the questions that remain in charge ransfer processes at the nanoscale. The ongoing efforts in mproving the time response and sensitivity of the elecronic setups, have already been demonstrated to enable n depth studies of reaction kinetics [7,60 ●●] and to proide mechanistic insights including particle mobility etc. 25,27,61 ●●] at a single entity level. Thanks to the relaive ease of employing NIA in different experimental seups, one of most exciting developments in the field will e the combination of NIA with optical [26,62,63] and pectroscopic methods [64 ●,65 ●●] . The implementation f these multi-method analytical systems in fluidic system or real time on-line monitoring in industrial production ines and for high-throughput, high-sensitivity lab-on-ahip devices for bio-sensing and medical applications may ikely further increase the already quickly increasing relvance of application electrochemical methods in these merging fields.

metadata.abstractText: We discuss here the design of functional nanoparticles and their study at the single entity level using nanoparticle impact electroanalysis (NIA). In particular, developments in electrochemical amplification (ECA) and transformative nanoparticle impact analysis (T-NIA) will be described that enable a better characterization of functional nanomaterials and their reactivity in their native (liquid) environment. This review highlights some outstanding works from the past two years that demonstrate the rapid progression in single entity nano-impact electrochemistry and discusses the remaining challenges to be overcome.
